{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title =Mega Dead Pixel | image= Mega Dead Pixel.jpeg | developer = [[About Fun]] | publisher = [[Chillingo]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | designer = | writer = | programmer = | composer = | engine = [[Unity engine]] | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone 8]] | released = '''iOS:'''17 October 2013
'''Android:''' 6 May 2014https://twitter.com/chillingo/status/463710007452639232http://games.tiscali.cz/tema/vyvoj-her-v-cesku-v-roce-2013-cast-1-65583 | genre = [[Arcade game]] }} '''''Mega Dead Pixel''''' is an [[Arcade game|arcade]] [[Indie game|indie]] video game developed by [[About Fun]] and published by [[Chillingo]]. The game had more than one million downloads during the first fourteen days after its initial release. The game was released for iOS, Android and Windows Phone.{{cite web |title=Vývoj her v Česku v roce 2013 |url=http://games.tiscali.cz/tema/vyvoj-her-v-cesku-v-roce-2013-cast-1-65583 |accessdate=26 November 2018}} ==Gameplay== It is an infinitely running game. The player controls a pixel who is falling down and has to avoid dangerous black pixels represented by various shapes. As he avoids these pixels, his own pixel is getting bigger by collecting white pixels. Furthermore, by brushing the shapes (falling next to them), ideally in a quick succession, player scores and the mega pixel bar is getting filled up. When its filled completely, pixel becomes the Mega Pixel and demoslishes everything in his way. Player can score by smashing shapes too, but that also reduces his size.{{cite web|url=http://www.148apps.com/reviews/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review » 148Apps » iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch App Reviews and News |publisher=148Apps |date=2013-10-21 |accessdate=2014-02-24}} There are also coins that player has to catch. He can buy for them some power-ups like pistols. Power-ups can also be bought for real money.{{cite web|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/2068444/mega-dead-pixel-review-free-falling-game-a-smashing-good-time.html |title=Mega Dead Pixel review: Free-falling game a smashing good time |publisher=Macworld |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}} == Reception == The game received positive and mixed reviews. It was praised for its concept, graphics and its soundtrack. On the other hand, it was criticised for its controls, difficulty and its stereotypical gameplay.{{cite web|url=http://www.appspy.com/review/7872/mega-dead-pixel |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review | iPhone & iPad Game Reviews |publisher=AppSpy.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezebo.com/games/mega-dead-pixel/review |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review |publisher=Gamezebo |date=2013-10-29 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.modojo.com/reviews/2013-10-21-mega-dead-pixel |title=Mega Dead Pixel iPad Review |publisher=Modojo.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mobot.net/mega-dead-pixel-ios-review-61808 |title=Mega Dead Pixel iOS review | App Reviews |publisher=Mobot.net |date=2013-10-25 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gameteep.net/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review |publisher=Gameteep |date=2013-10-31 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web |author= |url=https://community.phones4u.co.uk/mega-dead-pixel-app-review/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113135919/http://community.phones4u.co.uk/mega-dead-pixel-app-review/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-11-13 |title=Mega Dead Pixel: App Review - Phones 4u |publisher=Community.phones4u.co.uk |date=2013-11-13 |accessdate=2014-02-24 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cultofmac.com/251062/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel Has Retro Graphics, Music, And Difficulty (Review) |publisher=Cult of Mac |date=2013-10-25 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|last=Sanchez |first=Miranda |url=http://randomhavok.com/2013/11/05/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review |publisher=Random Havok |date=2013-11-05 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.idownloadblog.com/2013/10/18/mega-dead-pixel/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel plummets into the App Store |publisher=Idownloadblog.com |date=2013-10-18 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|author=Daniel Celeste |url=http://appadvice.com/review/quickadvice-mega-dead-pixel |title=Endlessly Fall While Growing Your Pixel And Destroying Others In Mega Dead Pixel |publisher=AppAdvice |date=2013-10-17 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cheatmasters.com/blog/2013/11/09/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel (Review) |publisher=Cheatmasters.com |date=2013-11-09 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://cakelessroses.blogspot.cz/2013/10/dead-pixel-review-that-one-dead-pixel.html |title=iOS Game Reviews: "Mega Dead Pixel" Review - That's One Dead Pixel |publisher=Cakelessroses.blogspot.cz |date=2013-10-17 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://appgamer.net/reviews/2013/oct/17/mega-dead-pixel/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel |publisher=AppGamer.net |date=2013-10-17 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutthegames.co.uk/feature_story.php?article_id=12700 |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review |publisher=AllAboutTheGames |date=2013-11-22 |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.capsulecomputers.com.au/2013/10/mega-dead-pixel-review/ |title=Mega Dead Pixel Review | Capsule Computers - Gaming & Entertainment News, Reviews, Interviews & Competitions |date=2013-10-17 |accessdate=2014-02-24}} Apple selected the game to be one of the best games of 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=521591001269963&l=027944c1a2 |title=About Fun - Tijdlijnfoto's |publisher=Facebook |date=2013-12-17 |accessdate=2014-02-24}} Game was selected as one of the best mobile games of 2013 in many online magazines.{{cite web|last=Ali |first=Zaib |url=http://ioshacker.com/games/10-insanely-addictive-games-iphone-ipad-or-ipod-touch |title=10 Insanely Addictive Games for Your iPhone, iPad or iPod touch |publisher=iOS Hacker |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://continue-play.com/2014/01/01/the-continue-play-awards-2013/ |accessdate=2 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103060611/http://continue-play.com/2014/01/01/the-continue-play-awards-2013/ |archivedate=3 January 2014 |title=The Continue Play awards 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cultofmac.com/259382/years-best-damn-ios-mac-games-2013-roundup/ |title=The Best Damn iOS Games Of 2013 (Year In Review) |publisher=Cult of Mac |date=2013-12-26 |accessdate=2014-02-24}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.about-fun.com/our-games/mega-dead-pixel Official site] [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Unity (game engine) games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:Windows Phone games]] {{mobile-game-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2018}} '''Narada Gana Sabha''' is one of the foremost music associations in the city of [[Chennai]], [[India]]. It regularly organises programmes during the [[Chennai Music Season]].<ref name="Muthiahp273">{{cite book | title=Madras Rediscovered| last=Muthiah| first=S.| year=2004| authorlink=S. Muthiah| publisher=East West Books (Madras) Pvt Ltd| isbn=81-88661-24-4|page=273}}</ref>
== History ==
The Narada Gana Sabha was founded on 9 February 1958, in [[Mylapore]].<ref name="thehindu_20080125">{{cite news|title=Narada Gana Sabha to celebrate golden jubilee next month|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=25 January 2008|url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/01/25/stories/2008012560110500.htm}}</ref> After functioning for three years from V. M. Street in Mylapore, the Sabha moved to Music Academy Hall.<ref name="thehindu_20080125"/> In 1972, the Sabha acquired land in T. T. K. Road where it constructed its own hall in February 1988.<ref name="thehindu_20080125" />
== Activities ==
The sabha regularly conducts [[music]], [[classical dance|dance]] and [[drama]] programmes during the annual [[Chennai Music Season]].<ref name="naradaganasabha">{{cite web|title=Narada Gana Sabha|publisher=Chennai December Music Season 2010|url=http://www.chennaidecemberseason.com/2010/11/narada-gana-sabha.html}}</ref> It also conducts an annual festival of its own.<ref name="thehindu_20110811">{{cite news|title=Come, see them dance a story|work=The Hindu|first=Vidya|last=Saranyan|url=http://www.thehindu.com/arts/dance/article2346573.ece|date=11 August 2011}}</ref>
== Notes ==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Organisations based in Chennai]] [[Category:Indian music]] [[Category:Music organisations based in India]]

The '''National Dance Alliance''' ('''NDA'''), originally named the '''NCA Superstar''', was established in 1999 as a “full service provider in the dance spirit industry”. The NDA is the sister company of the National Cheer Association (NCA), which was founded by Lawrence Herkimer in 1948.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/AboutUs.aspx|title = About Us|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034425/http://nda.varsity.com/AboutUs.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }} </ref> In 1976, the NCA created the NCA Superstar to make a distinction between the dance and cheerleading aspects of the company. Eventually in 1999, the NCA Superstar changed its name to the National Dance Alliance.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url = http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/national-cheerleaders-association-and-national-dance-alliance-championships-to-be-televised-on-cbs-sports-network-140036673.html|title = National Cheerleaders Association and National Dance Alliance Championships to be Televised on CBS Sports Network|date = 2012-02-22|accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = PR Newswire|publisher = Regional Business News|last = |first = }} </ref>
The National Dance Alliance (NDA) is the sister company of the [[National Cheerleaders Association|National Cheer Association]] (NCA) founded by [[Lawrence Herkimer]] in 1948. The NDA is an organization that provides high quality training and teaching to middle school, high school, and college dance teams around the country. NDA hosts many camps, clinics, competitions, and various performance events throughout the year for dancers to attend.<ref name=":02" /> Each year, the NCA/NDA hosts over 75,000 cheerleaders and dancers at their summer camps and over 1,500 teams from 45 states at their National Championships.<ref name=":12" />
The National Dance Alliance's core goals are to inspire young dancers and to teach them about the importance of teamwork. The NDA emphasizes that the primary purpose of a dance team is to raise spirit for the school’s athletic teams as well as the overall community. The NDA instills strong leadership skills in all of its dancers and teaches dance teams how to be role models at the schools they attend.<ref name=":02" /><!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE -->
==History== Lawrence Herkimer, a famous innovator in the world of cheerleading, founded the NCA in 1948.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/15/sports/ncaabasketball/15cheer.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title = Pyramid Builder|date = 2009-03-14|accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = The New York Times|publisher = The New York Times|last = Branch|first = John}}</ref> The NCA was the first cheerleading company to hold camps and clinics that invited cheerleaders and dancers from around the country to learn new tricks and improve their technique under the supervision of trained and qualified instructors. The NCA had always incorporated dance into its programs, by allowing dance, [[pom-pom]], or drill teams to learn alongside the cheerleaders.<ref name=":02"/> In 1976, the company made a distinction between cheerleading and dance by creating the NCA Superstar as the dance section of the company. The NCA Superstar eventually changed its name to the National Dance Alliance in 1999.<ref name=":12"/> The National Dance Alliance brand was established and is now a “full service provider in the dance spirit industry”.<ref name=":02"/>
The NCA and NDA are both a part of the [[Varsity Spirit|Varsity Spirit Corporation]], an organization that hosts competitions, offers camps and clinics to train dancers and cheerleaders, and sells cheer and dance apparel.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/_stories/2002-04-26-cover-side-business.htm#more|title = USATODAY.com - From Megaphones to Mega-profits.|date = 2002-04-26|accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = USA Today|publisher = |last = Brady|first = Erik}}</ref>
==Camps== The National Dance Association extends invitations to high school and college dance teams from all over the country to attend its summer or fall camps.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/allaboutcamp.aspx|title = Everything You Need To Know About Camp|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034435/http://nda.varsity.com/allaboutcamp.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref> Many of these camps are held at university campuses, hotels, and convention centers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/college_camps.aspx|title = College Camps|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006020040/http://nda.varsity.com/college_camps.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref> Teams that attend NDA’s camps get evaluated and receive personalized feedback from members of the NDA staff.<ref name=":2" /> These camps are intended to prepare teams for their upcoming season.<ref name=":12"/> NDA offers three different types of camps that dance teams can choose from including overnight camps, day camps, and home camps.
The overnight camp is either a three- or four-day session that is available to teams at all different technical levels. All NDA overnight camps offer classes that benefit all levels of training, including beginner, intermediate, advanced, and elite. The overnight camp gives participants the opportunity to audition to become an All-American Dancer. Participants selected to be All-American Dancers are given the opportunity to attend many special event performances hosted by the NCA and NDA all over the country.
The NDA day camps are two-, three-, or four-day sessions for teams that are not able to attend any of the overnight camps and instead would like to attend a camp where they do not spend the night. The day camps consist of the same curriculum as the NDA overnight camps; however, classes are held from 9am-5pm after which, participants are required to go home. Classes are offered in all styles of dance for all levels. Dancers are also eligible to audition to become an All-American Dancer at the NDA day camps.
The home camps are available to teams that would prefer to work privately with a trained NDA instructor in the privacy of their own school. This option allows teams to have a personalized teaching atmosphere that focuses on the specific needs of the team. Home camps give coaches the opportunity to create their own camp schedule that best fits their team. Coaches can choose from a wide variety of technique classes, choreography classes in many different styles, and team-building exercises for their team to participate in. Dancers can also be selected to audition to be an All-American Team Member.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/camptypes.aspx|title = Camp Types|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034648/http://nda.varsity.com/camptypes.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref>
==Competitions== The National Dance Alliance gives dance teams the opportunity to compete against one another at the NDA Classic Championships or Nationals. The invitation to compete at these competitions is extended to school and college dance teams, as well as All-Star dance teams.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/Championships.aspx|title = Championships|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006020025/http://nda.varsity.com/Championships.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref> The competitions are split up based on whether the dance team is at the collegiate, school, or all-star level.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/rules.aspx|title = Rules and Divisions|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006020113/http://nda.varsity.com/rules.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref> Each year, the NCA/NDA administers about 40 local, regional and national competitions nationwide.<ref name=":12"/>
===Nationals=== To compete at the National competitions, the NDA College Rule Book for College Teams states that teams must have qualified at the NDA Summer or Fall Camps, Regional or Classic competition, or by video submission. At the collegiate level, teams can be offered bids to the National Competition based on the team’s participation, conduct, and achievements at camp.<ref name=":4" />
=== Classical/Regional Championships === The NDA offers high school and middle school dance teams the opportunity to compete in their classical or regional championships. These competitions allow for teams to compete against other dance teams in their region. Compared to the national championships, the classical and regional competitions are less expensive and allow you to stay close to home. Competing in either of these types of competition can also qualify teams to compete in the NDA National Championship.<ref name=":3" />
==Special events==
===Christmas extravaganza=== The NDA gives dancers the chance to perform in the [[Disney Parks Christmas Day Parade|Walt Disney World Christmas Parade]]. This event is televised and aired on Christmas Day on ABC network. The trip is a four-day and three-night event that is held at [[Disney's Coronado Springs Resort|Disney’s Colorado Springs Resort]] in Florida. Dancers who participate in this event also get the privilege of visiting many of Disney World’s theme parks. Dancers eligible to attend this trip must attend a NCA or NDA camp or be an All-American Team Member or an All-American Nominee of a Varsity, Junior Varsity, Freshman or Junior High team. Also, all teams who won trophies or plaques in competitions, whether they are individuals or an entire team, may attend.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/christmas.aspx|title = NCA & NDA Christmas Extravaganza|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034653/http://nda.varsity.com/christmas.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref>
===London New Year's Day parade=== This event is open to all freshman, juniors, and seniors in high school who were selected to be an All-American Team Member. Dancers eligible to attend are able to perform in [[New Year's Day Parade|London’s New Year’s Day Parade]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/rome.aspx|title = London New Year's Day Parade|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034513/http://nda.varsity.com/rome.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref>
===Thanksgiving Day parades=== NDA gives dancers the opportunity to perform in a variety of parades around the country that occur on the morning of Thanksgiving. All-American Team Members can perform in the [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade|Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade]] in New York, the Houston Thanksgiving Day Parade, or the Philadelphia Thanksgiving Day Parade.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://nda.varsity.com/howtoqualify.aspx|title = How to Qualify|date = |accessdate = October 4, 2014|website = National Dance Alliance|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006034708/http://nda.varsity.com/howtoqualify.aspx|archivedate = October 6, 2014|df = }}</ref>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Dance organizations]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Nick Video / Turbo Nick | image = Nickelodeon 2009 logo.svg | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = | format = | creator = Nickelodeon | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = | language = | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = | company = | distributor = | channel = [[Nick.com]]
{{USA}} only | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = [[Nick.com]] | first_aired = July 1, 2005 (soft launch)
July 17, 2005 (as TurboNick)
April 1, 2009 (renamed to Nick Video) | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.nick.com/videos/ }} '''Nick Video''' (known as '''TurboNick''' in international markets) is an online [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]]-branded [[broadband]] channel that launched in 2005 as TurboNick. It features up to 15 hours of new programming every week and includes advertising. ==History== ===As TurboNick=== In its soft launch phase that commenced July 1, 2005, TurboNick garnered more than 1.25 million streams and officially launched with a full advertising and promotional campaign on July 17. Later on, Nickelodeon restricted the service to viewers only inside the United States and its territories. Shortly after Nickelodeon implemented these restrictions, ''TurboNick UK'' was launched, but unlike the original, the UK edition only features short clips of programs and is only available in the UK. An Australian version of TurboNick was launched in Early 2006 and still runs to this day (after re-brand) and a German version was launched in April 2007. A Latin American version of TurboNick exists under the name ''Nick Turbo''. On April 1, 2009, Nickelodeon renamed TurboNick to Nick Video, though some older videos have the TurboNick logo showing at some point in the video, like the "Extra Scoop" videos. ==Programming== ===Current Programming=== * ''[[The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius]]'' * ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' * ''[[Back at the Barnyard]]'' * ''[[Big Time Rush]]'' * ''[[Danny Phantom]]'' * ''[[Drake & Josh]]'' * ''[[El Tigre: The Adventures of Manny Rivera]]'' * ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]'' * ''[[Fanboy and Chum Chum]]'' * ''[[iCarly]]'' * ''[[Invader Zim]]'' * ''[[The Legend of Korra]]'' * ''[[The Loud House]]'' * ''[[Mr. Meaty]]'' * ''[[Ned's Declassified School Survival Guide]]'' * ''[[Pig Goat Banana Cricket]]'' * ''[[Planet Sheen]]'' * ''[[Sanjay & Craig]]'' * ''[[Sam & Cat]]'' * ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' * ''[[T.U.F.F. Puppy]]'' * ''[[Victorious]]'' * ''[[Zoey 101]]'' ===Former Programming=== * ''[[All Grown Up!]]'' * ''[[Bucket & Skinner's Epic Adventures]]'' * ''[[Catscratch]]'' * ''[[ChalkZone]]'' * ''[[Just Jordan]]'' * ''[[The Mighty B!]]'' * ''[[My Life as a Teenage Robot]]'' * ''[[The Naked Brothers Band (TV Series)|The Naked Brothers Band]]'' * ''[[Romeo!]]'' * ''[[Tak and the Power of Juju (TV series)|Tak and the Power of Juju]]'' * ''[[True Jackson, VP]]'' * ''[[Unfabulous]]'' * ''[[The X's]]'' ==See also== {{portal|Nickelodeon}} * [[Nick.com]] * [[Nicktropolis]] * [[Nickelodeon]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nick.com/videos/ Nick Video] * [http://mx.mundonick.com/videos Nick Latin America]* * [http://www.nickelodeon.com.au/videos Nick Australia] * [http://www.nick.co.kr/turbonick/ Turbonick Korea] (service for South Korea) * [http://www.nick.co.uk/clips/ Nick UK] (service for the United Kingdom and Ireland) * [http://www.nicktv.it/video Nick Italy] * [http://www.nick.de/videos Nick Germany] * [http://www.nickelodeon.be/videos Nick Netherlands and Belgium] * [http://www.nick.com.pl/wideo Nick Video Poland] * [http://www.nick-asia.com/videos Nick South East Asia ] * [http://www.nickcanada.com/video Nick Canada] {{Nickelodeon}} {{MTV Networks}} {{Viacom}} [[Category:Internet properties established in 2005]] [[Category:Nickelodeon]] [[Category:Children's television]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Penn & Teller Get Killed | image = Penn & Teller Get Killed.jpg | caption = VHS cover | director = [[Arthur Penn]] | producer = Timothy Marx
Arthur Penn | writer = [[Penn Jillette]]
[[Teller (magician)|Teller]] | starring = [[Penn & Teller]] | music = [[Paul Chihara]] | cinematography = Jan Weincke | editing = Jeffrey Wolf | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{Film date|1989|09|22}} | runtime = 89 min | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Penn & Teller Get Killed''''' is a 1989 [[black comedy]] film directed by [[Arthur Penn]] starring the [[magic (illusion)|magicians]] [[Penn & Teller]]. The duo play themselves in a satirical account of what the audience would perhaps imagine the pair doing in their daily lives. Most of the action involves [[Penn Jillette|Penn]] and [[Teller (magician)|Teller]] playing practical jokes on each other along with Penn's girlfriend, Carlotta ([[Caitlin Clarke]]). The final joke, as the title of the film implies, has serious consequences for all three. It was the last theatrical film to be directed by Arthur Penn, and received mostly negative reviews from critics.Nat Segaloff, ''Final Cuts: The Last Films of 50 Great Directors'', Bear Manor Media 2013 p 219-221 == Plot == Penn & Teller appear on a television show where Penn jokingly comments that he wishes someone were trying to kill him. Soon after, the magicians are off to a scheduled show in [[Atlantic City]]. At the airport, a religious zealot confronts Penn about his comments from the television show the night before. Teller and Carlotta play a prank on Penn while going through security and Penn gets back at Teller by planting a toy gun on him while at the airport. After exposing fraudulent psychic surgery to Carlotta's wealthy Uncle Ernesto, Penn and Teller are kidnapped by angry Filipinos wishing revenge for damaging their reputation. Immediately before being brutally tortured, the situation is revealed to Penn as a birthday prank played by Teller, Carlotta and Uncle Ernesto. Soon after, while leaving the theatre from their nightly performance, someone opens fire on Penn, shooting him in the arm. Teller is accused of hiring an assassin as a joke, but as time goes on it becomes clear that Teller is not part of the joke. Teller purchases a gun for self-defense and ''femme fatale'' Officer MacNamara vows to keep Penn safe from snipers. Officer MacNamara announces that a nameless villain, a supposed vehement Penn & Teller fan who dresses and acts like Penn, has been arrested. Penn and Teller get to tour his bizarre apartment turned Penn & Teller shrine. Teller innocuously disposes of his gun in a trashcan of the apartment. Shortly after MacNamara departs, Penn is stabbed in the stomach by an assailant on the street. Penn rushes off to hospital where, once Teller is out of sight, he appears perfectly fine. Teller proceeds to pursue the would-be assassin in a peculiar chase scene back to the apartment. The madman, dressed as Penn, forces Teller to enact a Penn & Teller routine with him, hanging in [[gravity boots]] in front of a camera. He then uses duct tape to secure the hapless Teller to the gravity boot rig. Officer MacNamara returns and the assassin leaves to finish off Penn. MacNamara confesses to Teller her contempt of Penn & Teller. The confused Teller is able to grab the gun from the wastebasket and threatens MacNamara with it. He hears a voice behind him and as the individual grabs him, he shoots the individual only to realize it's Penn, who appears to fall over dead. MacNamara laughs, thinking that it's a new joke. She then reveals herself as Carlotta. The implications of what has just happened suddenly catch up with them: The whole event had been a joke on Teller who turned everything around on the players. Teller, breaking silence for the first time, immediately thinks they switched the gun for a replica, but then realizes the gun he was holding is real and he just killed his partner. Teller turns the gun on himself. Carlotta, stricken with grief, throws herself out the window. Upon returning to his apartment and finding everyone dead, the "hired assassin", realizing he'll certainly be implicated in the deaths, shoots himself. Others who come into the apartment and find the carnage shoot themselves. Gunshots are heard in the distance, while the [[Bee Gees]] song "[[I Started a Joke]]" plays in the background. In a voice over, Penn explains this is the definitive end of it all. ==Cast== *[[Penn Jillette|Penn]] as Penn *[[Teller (magician)|Teller]] as Teller *[[Caitlin Clarke]] as Carlotta ** Celia McGuire as Officer McNamara *[[David Patrick Kelly]] as The Fan *[[Leonardo Cimino]] as Ernesto *[[Bill Randolph]] as Floor Director *[[Jon Cryer]] as Frat Boy ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0098073|title=Penn & Teller Get Killed}} * {{Mojo title|pennandtellergetkilled}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|penn_and_teller_get_killed}} * [http://www.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/feature/49671 ''Sight & Sound'' review] {{Penn & Teller}} {{Arthur Penn}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Penn And Teller Get Killed}} [[Category:1989 films]] [[Category:American black comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:1980s comedy films]] [[Category:American comedy-drama films]] [[Category:Fiction narrated by a dead person]] [[Category:Films directed by Arthur Penn]] [[Category:Films about magic and magicians]] [[Category:Films shot in Atlantic City, New Jersey]] [[Category:Films shot in New York City]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Penn Jillette]] [[Category:Screenplays by Teller (magician)]]

{{Infobox Wrestling promotion |name= Philippine Wrestling Revolution{{cite web|url=http://www.pwrcentral.com|title=Philippine Wrestling Revolution|work=pwrcentral.com}} |image= File:PWRevolutionlogo.png |acronym= PWR |established= December 22, 2013 |folded= |style= [[Professional wrestling]] |founders = Mark Javellana
(President)
Ouel Babasa
(Creative Director)
Bombay Suarez
(Head Trainer)
Jemm Steady
(Talent Relations) |website= http://www.pwrcentral.com }} '''Philippine Wrestling Revolution''' ('''PWR''') is an [[independent circuit|independent]] [[professional wrestling]] promotion based in the [[Philippines]]. PWR was founded in December 2013. ==History== Professional wrestling in the Philippines started in 1989 through the short-lived show called ''"Pinoy Wrestling"''. It aired on national television via [[People's Television Network|PTV-4]], with character actor Johnny Revilla as host and ringside reporter comedian Jimmy Fabregas. Its roster consisted of locally trained wrestlers such as Joe Pogi, King Cobra, Macho Franco, Caloy Bakal, and Max Buwaya. There were also [[Tag team match|tag teams]] such as The Smoky Mountain Brothers, The Bakal Boys, and Dr. Q’s henchmen The Brusko Brothers, Kamikaze Kid and Roboto. Women wrestlers like Aerobica and Pinay Wonder and midgets such as The Mikrobyos and The Tureritos were also featured. Other wrestlers include Juan Duwag, Waway The Wild Man, Turko Turero, Pinoy Ranger, Sultan Bato, Iggy Igorot, Lawin and Zorro. The show was discontinued in the early part of 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/sports/philippines/52526-pwr-reviving-pro-wrestling-philippines|title=PWR: Reviving pro wrestling in the Philippines|work=Rappler|author=Nissi Icasiano}} In 2012, the idea of forming PWR was born in a [[Facebook]] group. Wrestling fans from different parts of the country linked up and were added to the group to establish a wrestling company, discuss fantasy bookings, and conceptualize characters and gimmicks. This came about despite pro wrestling not being as popular in the Philippines since the end of the [[Attitude Era|WWE Attitude Era]] in the late 1990s and early 2000s as well as the exposure of [[kayfabe]]. The upstart promotion got an assist from veteran American pro wrestler [[Joe E. Legend]], who helped them in the preparations. Sometime between late 2013 and early 2014, the group was contacted by a Japanese promoter Ankei Tamashiro doing a show in the Philippines for [[Wrestling New Classic|WNC-Reina]], where two of the main attractions were former [[WWE]] and [[Extreme Championship Wrestling|ECW]] superstar [[Yoshihiro Tajiri|Tajiri]] and half-Filipina triple crown champion [[Shuri Kondo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/unblogged/articles/2014/01/28/1283972/ex-wwe-star-tajiri-wows-crowd-manil-wrestling-event|title=Ex-WWE star Tajiri wows crowd in Manila wrestling event|work=philstar.com}} The Japanese promoter's representative in Manila found PWR's Facebook page and asked the group to assist them in setting up and promoting the show in the country. These events further encouraged the group to pursue the idea of setting up the first-ever wrestling promotion in the country.{{cite web|url=http://johnsontranscript.com/2014/08/26/30-in-30-reborn-philippine-wrestling-revolutions-channel/|title=30 in 30 Reborn: Philippine Wrestling Revolution’s Channel - The Johnson Transcript|work=The Johnson Transcript}} The pioneer batch of aspiring professional wrestlers were officially trained by an American pro wrestler who goes by the name of Josh Bauserman, whom they met in Manila during the early stages of planning. The founders credit Bauserman for teaching them everything about pro wrestling, from in-ring maneuvers to backstage activities. PWR has recently expanded its reach within the international community as international wrestlers such as [[Billy Suede]] and Koto Hiro have joined their roster. In 2017, WWE officials were also in attendance during PWR Live: Bagong Yugto.https://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/other-sports/160545-pwr-live-bagong-yugto-wrestling-review-seizing-moment-wwe ==Events== The promotion held its inaugural event called '''''Renaissance''''' on September 27, 2014, at the Makati Cinema Square Arena, [[Makati City]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/other-sports/71145-pwr-renaissance-revival-pinoy-wrestling|title=PWR Renaissance: Breaking down the revival of Pinoy wrestling|work=Rappler}}{{cite web|url=http://www.geekypinas.com/2014/09/philippine-wrestling-revolution-presents-renaissance-pro-wrestling-event.html#axzz3IXoOOHuy|title=Philippine Wrestling Revolution Presents "Renaissance" Pro-Wrestling Event (Raffle)|work=geekypinas.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wheninmanila.com/renaissance-philippine-wrestling-revolution-inaugural-event/|title=Renaissance: Philippine Wrestling Revolution Inaugural Event|work=When In Manila}} PWR then held subsequent events to complete its calendar: '''''Terminus''''', '''''Vendetta''''', and '''''Wrevolution X''''', which is considered to be PWR's [[WrestleMania]] equivalent.{{cite web|url=http://astig.ph/renaissance-philippine-wrestling-revolution-live-event/|title=Renaissance: Philippine Wrestling Revolution live event|work=ASTIG.PH}} On August 15, 2015, PWR held an event called '''''PWR Live''''', still at the Makati Cinema Square Arena. Multiple events named PWR Live have been staged since. To date, 2 PWR shows have been aired on television (on tape delay) via TV5: ''Terminus'' (2014){{cite web|url=http://sports.tv5network.com/shows/195/pwr/33DB3C87DB/pwr-terminus-main-event-jdl-and-bombay-vs-royal-flush|title=PWR Terminus - Main Event: JDL and Bombay vs. Royal Flush|work=Sports5 Portal|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307125310/http://sports.tv5network.com/shows/195/pwr/33DB3C87DB/pwr-terminus-main-event-jdl-and-bombay-vs-royal-flush|archivedate=2016-03-07|df=}} and ''PWR Live'' (August 2015){{cite web|url=http://sports.tv5network.com/shows/195/pwr/9A7C9D75A8/pwr-episode-1-1|title=PWR: Episode 1.1|work=Sports5 Portal|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307124035/http://sports.tv5network.com/shows/195/pwr/9A7C9D75A8/pwr-episode-1-1|archivedate=2016-03-07|df=}} After its second Renaissance event in September, PWR held a second PWR Live event in November, but in a new venue, at the iAcademy Auditorium in Makati City. Since then, all PWR events have been hosted there. Celebrity guests who have been attendance in previous events include Quark Henares, [[Stanley Chi]], Red Ollero, [[Darius Semaña]], radio DJs Poch and Tino, Mihk Vergara, King Palisoc, Miko Livelo, Brian Wilson of [[Juan Direction]], Ramon Bautista, and Ryan Rems Sarita. On February 5, 2016, PWR held a house show at the LBD Sports Arena in Candelaria, Quezon, its first outside Metro Manila.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/PHWrestlingRevo/photos/a.1518572128404300.1073741828.1517681678493345/1651307705130741/?type=3|title=PWR invades Quezon|work=facebook.com}} ===List of events=== {{main '''Prostitution in South Africa''' is illegal for both buying and selling sex, as well as related activities such as [[brothel]] keeping and [[pimping]].<ref name="spl">{{cite web|title=Sexuality, Poverty and Law Programme|url=http://spl.ids.ac.uk/sexworklaw/countries|publisher=Institute of Development Studies|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref> However, it remains widespread.<ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=Chats Bin|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref> Law enforcement is poor.<ref name="spl" />
In 2013 the Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Task Force (SWEAT) estimated that there were between 121,000 and 167,000 [[prostitute]]s in [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Estimating the size of the sex worker population in South Africa, 2013|url=http://www.sweat.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Sex-Workers-Size-Estimation-Study-2013.pdf|publisher=SWEAT|accessdate=9 December 2017}}</ref>
[[HIV]],<ref name="sowetanlive">{{cite web|title=No condoms, more money say prostitutes|url=https://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2015-09-11-no-condoms-more-money-say-prostitutes/|website=Sowetanl Lve|accessdate=10 December 2017|date=11 September 2015}}</ref> [[child prostitution]] (including [[sex tourism]])<ref name="ecpat">{{cite web|title=Executive Summary South Africa|url=http://www.ecpat.org/wp-content/uploads/legacy/Ex_Summary_AF_S-AFRICA_FINAL.pdf|website=[[ECPAT]]|accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> and [[human trafficking]]<ref name="state2">{{cite web|title=2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271281.htm|publisher=US Department of State|accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> are problems in the country.
==Legal and regulatory framework== The [[Immorality Act, 1927]] prohibited extramarital sex between "Europeans" and "natives".<ref name="immoral27">{{cite wikisource | title=Immorality Act, 1927 }}</ref> This was redefined by the Immorality Amendment Act, 1950 as illicit carnal intercourse between "Europeans" and "non-Europeans",<ref name="immoral50">{{cite wikisource | title=Immorality Amendment Act, 1950 }}</ref>
The [[Immorality Act, 1957]], later renamed the [[Sexual Offences Act, 1957]], repealed the 1927 Act (as amended) and introduced new offences for [[brothel]] keeping, [[pimping]] and [[Procuring (prostitution)|procuring]].<ref name="immoral57">{{cite wikisource | title=Immorality Act, 1957 }}</ref> [[Interracial sex]] was now criminalised as unlawful carnal intercourse between "white" and "coloured" people.<ref name="immoral57" />
The [[Criminal Procedure Act, 1977|Criminal Procedure Act 51 of 1977]] criminalised "committing an immoral or indecent act with such other person" and also [[soliciting]] for the same.<ref>{{cite web|title=Criminal Procedure Act 51 of 1977|url=http://www.justice.gov.za/legislation/acts/1977-051.pdf|website=JUTA's Statutes of South Africa|accessdate=9 December 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523214524/http://www.justice.gov.za/legislation/acts/1977-051.pdf|archivedate=23 May 2012}}</ref>
Municipal by-laws also contained provisions about prostitution.
As part of the repeal of many [[petty apartheid]] laws under the government of [[P. W. Botha]],<ref name="back">{{cite book|title=South Africa: no turning back|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_BeirIIXLyYC|first=Shaun|last=Johnson|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=1989|isbn=978-0-253-35395-5}}</ref> the Immorality and Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Amendment Act 1985 repealed the interracial restrictions of the Immorality Acts.<ref name="immoral95">{{cite wikisource | title=Immorality and Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Amendment Act, 1985 }}</ref>
The Immorality Amendment Act, 1988 renamed the Immorality Act, 1957 to the [[Sexual Offences Act, 1957]] and criminalised the act of prostitution. It also made the provisions of the 1957 Act gender neutral.<ref name="immoral88">{{cite wikisource | title=Immorality Amendment Act, 1988 }}</ref>
In 2002, an appeal by brothel keepers and prostitutes in the country's [[Constitutional Court of South Africa|Constitutional Court]], submitting that the laws on prostitution were in breach of the [[Constitution of South Africa|constitution]], was dismissed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prostitution 'still illegal' in SA|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/2314547.stm|website=BBC News|accessdate=10 December 2017|date=9 October 2002}}</ref>
The most recent legislative change was the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act, 2007, section 11 which added Section 20(1)(aA) of the SOA, which states that any person who has unlawful carnal intercourse or commits an act of indecency with any other person for reward, is guilty of an offence, effectively criminalising the client as well as the prostitute.<ref name="soa07">{{cite wikisource | title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2017 a report by the [[South African Law Reform Commission]], recommended that the current law be retained (proffered option), or that prostitution should be decriminalised but third party involvement remain illegal.<ref name="lrc">{{cite web|title=Long-awaited report on adult prostitution in South Africa released|url=https://www.enca.com/south-africa/long-awaited-report-on-adult-prostitution-in-safrica-released|website=ENCA|accessdate=9 December 2017|date=26 May 2017}}</ref>
===Decriminalisation=== Decriminalisation has been under active discussion since 2009. Currently the South African Law Reform Commission has four proposals that were submitted for public discussion ranging from criminalisation to decriminalisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmg.org.za/files/docs/090507salrc-adultprost.pdf|title= South African Law Reform Commission Project 107, Discussion paper on sexual offences and adult prostitution|publisher=Pmg.org.za|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
In the run-up to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 Football World Cup]], there were calls to decriminalise and regulate prostitution when an estimated 40,000 prostitutes were expected to travel to South Africa for the tournament.<ref name="autogenerated1" />
In March 2012, the [[ANC Women's League]] came out in favor of decriminalisation, and stated that they will campaign for this to become an [[ANC]] policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=ANC Women's League wants to decriminalise prostitution|url=http://gatewaynews.co.za/2012/03/27/anc-womens-league-wants-to-decriminalise-prostitution/|website=Gateway News|accessdate=10 December 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504214147/http://gatewaynews.co.za/2012/03/27/anc-womens-league-wants-to-decriminalise-prostitution/|archivedate=4 May 2012|date=26 March 2012}}</ref> It is argued that decriminalisation "would challenge the stigma that surrounds sex workers. It would help secure their human rights and dignity, and make for safer work and living conditions for them."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2013-01-14-sex-workers-vulnerability-is-our-vulnerability |title=Sex workers' vulnerability is our vulnerability |publisher=Daily Maverick |date=2013-01-14 |accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> Decriminalising prostitution would limit the power the police have on sex workers and it would stop the police or law enforcers from taking advantage of sex workers. Police enforcement is rigorous and police taking and accepting bribes by the police and their clients is common place.
In April 2013, the [[Commission for Gender Equality]] also stated its support for decriminalization. They argued that current laws violate sections of the constitution, and that sex workers would be better protected if the law is changed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enca.com/south-africa/decriminalise-sex-work-cge |title=Decriminalise sex work: CGE |publisher=eNCA |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Task Force (SWEAT), is a group based in South Africa that has been working to decriminalize sex work and eventually legalize it. They also provide health services for sex workers since they can't access them elsewhere. They have launched different programs to bring awareness to problems facing sex workers such as Sex Work Empowerment and Enabling Environment (SWEEP), #SayHerName, advocacy and law reform, and Sisonke movement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sweat.org.za/what-we-do/|title=What We Do {{!}} SWEAT|work=SWEAT|access-date=2017-12-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Police violence == Sex workers are at a disadvantage when it comes to the police, since they are facing extreme violence and abuse from them, they have no one to turn to in times of trouble. In an interview with one sex worker in Cape Town, she said: "The colored police officer grabbed me, and my clothes came off. Then they pepper sprayed me in my mouth and beat me".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Manoek|first=Stacey-Leigh|date=August 2012|title=A Report on Human Rights Violations by Police Against Sex Workers in South Africa|url=http://www.sweat.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Human-Rights-Violations-WLC-1.pdf|journal=Women's Legal Centre|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Many sex workers face random and unjustified violence from the police and can't report that violence to anyone. As many as 7 out of 10 sex workers have endured police brutality in some form, whether it's beating or rape.<ref name=":0" />
==2010 World Cup== There were fears of increased prostitution in connection with the [[2010 Football World Cup]], some sources estimating that an extra 40,000 sex workers would enter South Africa for the competition.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Cup 2010: 40,000 prostitutes to enter South Africa|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/7374301/World-Cup-2010-40000-prostitutes-to-enter-South-Africa.html|website=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=9 December 2017|date=5 Mar 2010}}</ref> As a result, there were calls for prostitution to be legalised and regulated to help control AIDS and STDs and for the protection of the sex workers.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|title= SA prostitution plans condemned|publisher= BBC|date=|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7509357.stm|accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref> However this generated considerable opposition<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and no changes were made to the laws.
Despite the fears, there was little evidence of increased prostitution.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Sex Work during the 2010 FIFA World Cup: Results from a Three-Wave Cross-Sectional Survey|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=6|issue=12|pages=e28363|pmc=3233553|date=7 December 2011|author1=Delva|first1=W|last2=Richter|first2=M|last3=De Koker|first3=P|last4=Chersich|first4=M|last5=Temmerman|first5=M|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0028363|pmid=22163298}}</ref>
==HIV== {{see also|HIV/AIDS in South Africa}} South Africa has one of the world's largest [[HIV]] epidemics.<ref name="sowetanlive" /> A study by the SA National Aids Council (Sanac) estimated that there was a 60% infection rate,<ref>{{cite web|title=60 percent of sex workers are HIV positive|url=http://www.health24.com/Medical/HIV-AIDS/News/60-percent-of-sex-workers-are-HIV-positive-20150113|website=Health 24|accessdate=10 December 2017|date=5 July 2016}}</ref> although this varies from area to area, for example, Johannesburg 72%, Durban 54% and Cape Town 40%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report: South African health and HIV survey among female sex workers|url=https://www.health-e.org.za/2016/03/16/2014-sex-workers-hiv-survey/|website=Health E-News|accessdate=10 December 2017|date=16 March 2016}}</ref>
The reluctance to use [[condoms]] has contributed significantly to the epidemic.<ref name="sowetanlive" /><ref name="avert">{{cite web|title=Sex Workers, HIV & AIDS|url=https://www.avert.org/professionals/hiv-social-issues/key-affected-populations/sex-workers|website=AVERT|accessdate=10 December 2017|date=2 May 2017}}</ref> However condom distribution by the government<ref name="lrc" /> AND HIV communication programmes have reduced the rate of new instances.<ref name="avert" />
==Child prostitution== [[Child prostitution]] is a problem in the country. Whilst there are no reliable figures available, it has been estimated that there are as many as 30,000 children involved.<ref name="ecpat" /> South Africa has become one of the major destinations for underage sex tourism in Africa. [[Cape Town]], [[Johannesburg]], [[Port Elizabeth]] and [[Durban]] have become popular destinations for this.<ref name="ecpat" />
Criminal gangs recruit children from poor rural areas and take them to the large cities for [[Commercial sexual exploitation of children|commercial sexual exploitation]].<ref name="state2" />
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|human trafficking in South Africa}} South Africa is a source, transit, and destination country for women and children subjected to [[sex trafficking]].<ref name="state2" /> Local criminal gangs dominate child sex trafficking. [[Nigerian]] gangs control the sex industry in several provinces. [[Thailand|Thai]] and [[China|Chinese]] nationals control the sex trafficking of Asian women. [[Russia]]n and [[Bulgaria]]n organised crime control trafficking in Cape Town.<ref name="state2" />
Women from [[Thailand]], [[China]], [[Brazil]], Eastern Europe, Asia, and neighbouring African countries are trafficked into South Africa and forced to work as prostitutes.<ref name="state2" /> Women from South Africa are trafficked to Europe.<ref name="state2" />
South Africa is listed as a [[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2 Watch List]] country by the [[US Department of State]]'s [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]].<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=South Africa 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282748.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>

Human Trafficking in South Africa: Root Causes and Recommendations] *[http://www.wsws.org/articles/1999/oct1999/saf-o05.shtml Cape Town promotes sex tourism] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071110181325/http://health.osf.lt/downloads/news/1_Justice_Kate.ppt Liesl Gerntholtz: Sex work and the law in South Africa – hit and miss?] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120305024300/http://www.iss.co.za/uploads/SWEATISSSUBJUN07.PDF ISS/SWEAT submission to SALRC June 2007] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101201231607/http://womensnet.org.za/campaign/decriminalise-sex-work-now Women's Net: Decriminalisation of sex work]
